@luoruisichuan  You can find the doc in ipython by `?mx.symbol.Concat`.

 The concat code is in c++, you can find it by searching the github(for example: [https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=Concat&type=Code](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=Concat&type=Code)).

but for two symbols, just as cd3x3 and cproj ,
cd3x3    96×28×28
cproj      32×28×28
I think,  the two symbls can only be concated on the dim=0, i.e., 
concat=mx.symbol.Concat(_[cd3x3, cproj], dim=0),  and concat=mx.symbol.Concat(_[cd3x3, cproj], dim=1) is not correct,  is there any problem?
thanks.
@wangg12 Thank you very much! I 'll try this

@luoruisichuan You can just verify it in several lines of code in ipython.

```
import numpy as np
import mxnet as mx
a= np.ones((96,28,28))
b=np.ones((32,28,28))
a1 = mx.nd.array(a)
b1 = mx.nd.array(b*2)
aV = mx.sym.Variable('a')
bV = mx.sym.Variable('b')
cat = mx.sym.Concat(aV, bV, dim=0)
cat1 = mx.sym.Concat(aV, bV, dim=1)
exe = cat.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'a':a1, 'b':b1})
exe.outputs[0].shape  # this is rught
exe1 = cat1.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'a':a1, 'b':b1}) # this would be wrong
```

So the answer of your question is correct.

thanks.
I get the reason.  batchsize dim is omited, and the actual symbol are 
cd3x3    batchsize×96×28×28
cproj     batchsize×32×28×28
so,   concat=mx.symbol.Concat([cd3x3, cproj], dim=1) is correct.

Ok Thanks for your reply. I found the problem might be this as shown below. Please try the below code, where there is only one conv layer with big dilation and num_filter. Normally, if I fix the input size, it uses only 800 MB memory, but if I vary the input size, more than 4000 MB will be used. There seems a lot of memory that could be squeezed. @sxjscience 
Try this out:

```
net = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=mx.symbol.Variable(name='data'), kernel=(3,3),pad=(12,12), num_filter=150, dilate=(12,12), workspace=2048)

e = net.simple_bind(ctx=mx.gpu(0),
                    grad_req="null",
                    data=(1, 2048, 80, 80))
import random
for i in range(1000):
    temp_shape = (1, 2048, random.randint(50, 80), random.randint(50, 80))
    e_t = e.reshape(data=temp_shape)
    e_t.forward(is_train=False)
    output = e_t.outputs[0].copyto(mx.cpu()).asnumpy()
```

I am working on one example of this

There are two ways you can do it.
1. modify ImageLabelMap in src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc to use a database
2. write your own data iter in python following /plugin/opencv/opencv.py:ImageListIter. You can use a database to store the data and labels or use recordio and pack data and label into the same record using self defined datastructure.

@antinucleon 
I was going to look into modifying embedding-inl.h Let me know if you are doing something similar along this line. 

Well here's the issue, currently the mx.sym.Embedding layer does not account for PAD symbols. So when a, out-of-range index is given to the mx.sym.Embedding layer, it returns a non-initialized vector. What is needed is for the Embedding layer to return an all zero vector, and for the backpropagation to ignore training on the LSTMs when there's a PAD from the embedding layer.

We can use ignore_label for the softmaxoutputs, but there's currently nothing for the inputs...

The current bucketing tutorial from @pluskid uses zeros. But the embedding layer treats that zero as any other symbol, and will include backpropagating the gradient to the embedding vector representing the zero or PAD.

@antinucleon 
the `mx.sym.Embedding function` needs to have 

```
ignore_label (float, optional, default=-1) – the label value will be ignored during backward (only works if use_ignore is set to be true).
use_ignore (boolean, optional, default=False) – If set to true, the ignore_label value will not contribute to the backward gradient
```

This has implications for coding a Sequence to Sequence RNN

You have to add -llog in the Makefile of the amalgamation.

For example, instead of

> CFLAGS=-std=c++11 -Wno-unknown-pragmas -Wall
> ifneq ($(MIN), 1)
>   CFLAGS += -I${OPENBLAS_ROOT} -I${OPENBLAS_ROOT}/include
>   LDFLAGS+= -L${OPENBLAS_ROOT} -L${OPENBLAS_ROOT}/lib -lopenblas
> endif

use this

> CFLAGS=-std=c++11 -Wno-unknown-pragmas -Wall
> LDFLAGS = -llog
> ifneq ($(MIN), 1)
>   CFLAGS += -I${OPENBLAS_ROOT} -I${OPENBLAS_ROOT}/include
>   LDFLAGS+= -L${OPENBLAS_ROOT} -L${OPENBLAS_ROOT}/lib -lopenblas
> endif

FWIW `nccl` is also much faster than a vanilla copy/reduce tree (a few x), and doesn't require a large copy buffer (https://github.com/NVIDIA/nccl/blob/b3a9e1333d9e2e1b8553b5843ba1ba4f7c79739d/src/core.h#L38, https://github.com/NVIDIA/nccl/blob/620491a64915354a827839dd8a2b86651cb0c187/src/all_reduce.cu#L35-L49), but there are still some annoying deadlocks with with concurrent synchronizations. It might be worth having it as an option - https://github.com/caffe2/caffe2/tree/master/caffe2/contrib/nccl might be useful.
use `export CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=1` to use GPU 1 only

You should specify `lr_mult` in corresponding symbol's attribute.
`set_lr_mult` and `set_wd_mult` are invoked in `__init__` to construct a dictionary named `self.lr_mult` which is used to determine specified learning rate of params.

I think @freesouls means continuous training on have-seen user/item with pre-trained model, where we use fresh data to update the model/parameter. 

However, is not that obvious to handle those never seen item/user. It should re-allocate the memory, redefine network size and load pre-trained parameters for those have seen. And I'm not sure if this way is theoretically correct or guarantee, feel free to comment below if anyone has any opinions :)

@antinucleon on-the-fly graph build/execution you mean like the imperative approach similar to Torch?

I think using `ignore_label` on the softmax loss should be good. Input can be padded as zero or whatever. It should be fine because when the loss hit `ignore_label`, the gradients are zero, therefore, due to chain-rule that particular example (frame) does not contribute to the gradient accumulation for all the model parameters.

However, there do have some caveat. For example, you need to remember to ignore those padded labels when computing metrics (accuracy could be higher if all zeros are counted). Also, if you use BatchNorm, then the statistics counter are still accumulating those zeros. etc.

@freddycct My understanding is that the chain-rule makes the back-propagation a series of multiplications. If one of the components (the loss) sets the multiplier to be zero, the whole chain will be zero. So the embedding layer will not get garbage gradient if the corresponding label is `ignore_label`. Do you agree?

You might find some of the following discussion useful:

#647
#910 (includes a link to code for a multilabel softmax layer; I haven't tried it yet)

I just posted a related question (#2929) about using an NDArrayIter with grouped outputs.

@pluskid Let me give an example of what I tried...

Let's say I have a sequence (X1, X2) that maps to (Y1, Y2) and they are in a bucket with encoder length 3, decoder length 4 according to the figure I showed. Note: I have a RNN that is made up of encoder RNN and decoder RNN, instead of just one RNN.

The training input is then given as
(0, X1, X2, EOS, Y1, Y2, 0)
the training label is
(Y1, Y2, EOS, 0)
Note: I did not connect a softmaxoutput loss to the encoder portion of the RNN.

Then after training for a very small example, in which training loss is almost zero...
the prediction for (0, X1, X2, EOS) gives (Y1, Y2) but the prediction for (X1, X2, EOS) gives some other results instead of (Y1, Y2). 

That means the presence or absence of the PAD symbol affects the forward calculations. I think it should not be this way, (0, X1, X2, EOS) should give same results as (X1, X2, EOS). 

The issue is MXNet does not recognize PAD inputs at the Embedding layer but only PAD outputs at the softmaxlosslayer.

#647 and #2929 are multi-task learning and not quite related to my question. Well, I could consider each label in my problem as a sub-task, but I've got hundreds of labels at hand...

I think [multilabel-layer-mxnet](https://github.com/jimxinbo/multilabel-layer-mxnet), as mentioned in #910, can be used for my problem. But according to #1658, it seems MXNet can directly deal with that.
